Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Break-Even Analysis for Management Accounting
headline: Become acquainted with cost-volume-profit analysis theory and technical methods in this free online course.
description: This 'Break-even Analysis for Management Accounting' course discusses the essential cost-volume-profit analysis theory and management accountants' techniques in creating organisational value. This course allows learners to develop a technical understanding of the effect of volume and fixed costs on profit. In addition, course participants learn how to manipulate break-even analysis ratios that enable sophisticated planning.

courseDescription:
This course overviews the fundamental cost-volume-profit analysis theories and specialised techniques. This knowledge will enable you to understand the interaction between fixed costs, production volume and profitability. In addition, you will become acquainted with break-even analysis ratios that allow scenario analysis with a focus on minimum volumes, standard selling price or maximum fixed costs. Learning this will help you generate a required return on investment based on the interaction of selling price, variable costs, fixed costs and output volume over a fixed period.

This course develops technical insight and skills in cost-volume-profit analysis. Knowing this analysis enables calculations such as the margin of safety and grants strategic insight into operations configuration to achieve a required return. Successful course participants will be able to analyse the cost structure of an operation, project or proposed venture.

Learners will understand how to establish minimum levels of activity or maximum levels of cost to reach the desired outcome based on the interaction between selling volumes and variable and fixed costs. Developing these skills enables sophisticated planning when combined with other techniques and theories, such as price elasticity of demand and risk and growth theories. These, in turn, relate to the cost of capital, which represents inputs for a break-even analysis. So enrol today and start your journey toward gaining a competitive edge.

Start Course Now

All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module provides an overview of the essential break-even analysis theories and techniques used in an organisation's decision-making and performance management activities.

modules.name: Module
topics: Break-Even Analysis for Management Accounting - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Define cost-volume-profit analysis. 
    • Identify the elements of a cost-volume-profit calculation.
    • Describe the contribution to the sales ratio. 
    • Discuss the break-even point.
    • Contrast the margin of safety and operational gearing of entities. 
    • Compute required revenue. 
    • Analyse operational gearing ratios.
    • Compare the contribution to sales ratios of entities. 
    • Discuss the concept of required revenue. 
    • Summarize the significance of operational gearing.

  • Cost-Volume-Profit (CVP) Analysis

    • New Tab
      Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • C/S ratio 
      Cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis
      CVP analysis is based on the contribution and assesses the following measures for a single product:
      - contribution to sales (C/S) ratio
      - break-even point
      - margin of safety
      Cost-volume-profit (CVP) analysis
      CVP analysis is based on the contribution and assesses the following measures for a single product:
      - contribution to sales (C/S) ratio
      - breakeven point
      - margin of safety
    • C/S ratio
      The contribution to sales ratio is extremely useful in manipulating other figures under the CVP umbrella. Contribution to sales indicates the amount of contribution earned for every currency unit of revenue. The C/S ratio is sometimes referred to as the profit volume ratio (P/V ratio).


      Contribution to sales is calculated by dividing the contribution earned, i.e. revenue less marginal cost, by the selling price or total revenue to express the relationship as a ratio.

      The C/S ratio can also be used to calculate required revenue if fixed costs and the required amount of profit are available.

      The contribution to sales ratio is extremely useful in manipulating other figures under the CVP umbrella. Contribution to sales indicate the amount of contribution earned for every currency unit of revenue. The C/S ratio is sometimes referred to as the profit volume ratio (P/V ratio).


      Contribution to sales is calculated by dividing the contribution earned i.e. revenue less marginal cost with the selling price or total revenue to express the relationship as a ratio.

      The C/S ratio can also be used to calculate required revenue if fixed costs and the required amount of profit is available.

  • Cost-Volume-Profit (CVP) Analysis

  • Multi-product breakeven analysis
    In a multi-product situation, a weighted average C/S ratio is calculated by dividing total contribution in the standard sales mix by total revenue from sales in the standard sales mix. 

    The break-even point in sales revenue is then calculated by dividing fixed cost by the weighted average C/S ratio. Alternatively, the break-even point can be calculated in units by using the weighted average contribution per unit.

    Target profit and required revenue in a multi-product environment
    The approach is the same as in a single product situation but with the weighted average contribution to sales ratio.
    Required revenue = (required profit + fixed costs) / weighted average C/S ratio

    Multi-product profit-volume chart
    In a multi-product environment, two lines must be shown on the profit-volume graph; one straight line where a constant mix between the product is assumed; and a bow-shaped line presenting sales in order of profitability, i.e. a cumulative profit/loss calculation assuming market demand for the most profitable product is met in full before demand for the second most profitable product is satisfied and so forth. 

  • Cost-Volume-Profit (CVP) Analysis

  • Example: Break-Even Ratios - Single Product 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The contribution to sales (C/S) ratio is calculated by dividing the contribution by the selling price, i.e. ($48/$120 = 0.40). The C/S ratio can then be used to calculate the break-even revenue (fixed cost divided by the C/S ratio), i.e. ($24,000/0.40 = $60,000). The margin of safety is calculated by subtracting the break-even point from the budgeted revenue, i.e. $264,000 - $60,000 = $204,000. Required revenue = (Required profit + Fixed costs  / CS ratio).

The margin of safety is calculated by subtracting the break-even point from the budgeted revenue, i.e. $264,000 - $60,000 = $204,000. Required revenue = (Required profit + Fixed costs  / CS ratio). 

  • Lesson Summary

  • Break-even Analysis for Management Accounting:
    • CVP analysis is based on contribution and assessment measures for a single product.
    • The contribution to the sales ratio is extremely useful in manipulating other figures under the CVP umbrella.
    • Contribution to sales indicates the amount of contribution earned for every currency unit of revenue.
    •  The C/S ratio is sometimes referred to as the profit volume ratio (P/V ratio).
    • The break-even point is the revenue or contribution level equal to total or fixed cost and at which no profit or loss is made.
    • Expected profit can be calculated using the margin of safety in units and contribution per unit figures.
    • The margin of safety represents the number of budgeted unit sales in excess of the break-even point, and from this point onwards, every unit that is sold contributes towards profit in the proportion of contribution to revenue per unit.
    • Operational gearing refers to the proportion of fixed to variable costs an organisation incurs in producing its products or services.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Break-even Analysis for Management Accounting:
    • CVP analysis is based on contribution and assessment measures for a single product.
    • The contribution to the sales ratio is extremely useful in manipulating other figures under the CVP umbrella.
    • Contribution to sales indicates the amount of contribution earned for every currency unit of revenue.
    •  The C/S ratio is sometimes referred to as the profit volume ratio (P/V ratio).
    • The break-even point is the revenue or contribution level equal to total or fixed cost and at which no profit or loss is made.
    • Expected profit can be calculated using the margin of safety in units and contribution per unit figures.
    • The margin of safety represents the number of budgeted unit sales in excess of the break-even point, and from this point onwards, every unit that is sold contributes towards profit in the proportion of contribution to revenue per unit.
    • Operational gearing refers to the proportion of fixed to variable costs an organisation incurs in producing its products or services.
